subject: Does spelling matter?
msgSnippet: ... [WW]I don t think it should matter how you spell something, even in Quikscript. [SB] Standardized spelling is required for speed reading.  It is something
messageBody:
--- "wonder_roast" wrote:
[WW]I don't think it should matter how you spell something, even in
Quikscript.

[SB] Standardized spelling is required for speed reading. It is
something that the printing industry will insist on.
For email and informal communication, it does not make that much
difference.

[WW] the word 'letter' is spelled the same way in England and
Australia as it is here. Yet, in those 2 countries, they pronounce
it more like "lettah." They don't seem to be complaining about the
spelling

[SB] I would not have a problem with either <leta> or <letr> or
<letar> where [a] represents the turned e or schwa as in keyboard
Shavian.


[WW] make an abjad for English (an alphabet which normally only
indicates consonants, but usually has a way to indicate vowels
should indication be necessary). I've been working
on one myself, and it is rather difficult, but it can be done.

[SB] That is basically what we have when we take out all the
misleading or ambiguous vowel letters. Some abjads have a way to
indicate vowels or semi-vowels but I wouldn't say that most do.

Since nearly half of the phonemes in English are vowels, I don't
think that a consonatal script would work that well.

Speedwriting eliminates all of the short vowels that are not
onsets. Cut spelling eliminates post accentual schwas. letter =
letr, little = litl. prison = prisn. This kind of strategy is
workable.

Here is an English syllabary:
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/saundspel/files/GP-tables/syllabary-
english75.gif

> For foreign learners of English,
> vowel diacritics/letters can be added to aid them in learning the
> pronunciation, like in Hebrew.

[SB] One of Tolkein's scripts did this.

Regards,
Steve
